text: this isn't just how to replace the tip
of your cue this is how to shape it too
it's ready to play with straightaway
afterwards this is breaking life welcome
back and if this is your first time
watching one of our videos then it's
fantastic to have you here there are an
awful lot of players out there who will
only ever get their tips put on
professionally but I found there's no
difference between this and the ones
I've put on myself and since I've had
hundred breaks with the tips I put on
the cue myself here's how you can save a
bit of money by doing it on your own I
noticed his tips started playing
unusually and found what was wrong with
it was half the ferrule had actually
gone through the bottom of the tip the
best way to take it off is with a knife
like this if you're worried about
cutting your hand in any way then just
put a cloth around your hand so the
knife can't cut it once you've removed
the tip you want to get rid of any
remnants of the tip or glue that was
used to put it on previously when you're
doing this you're gonna be scraping off
bits of wood and ferrule from the top of
your cue so you want to make sure you're
keeping that surface as flat as possible
so that tip doesn't wobble when you
stick it on you can do this best by
scraping from 3/4 of the way across to
the edge and then once you've done this
check the tip fits on the cue nice and
flat I'm using Q sole tips which are
layered tips and if you want to know how
to buy them there's a link to them in
the description with any tips your
sticking on I'd recommend roughing up
the bottom surface so it sticks easier
to the Q but with Q sole tips there's a
painted surface that you have to
actually sand off before you can stick
it on and you need to be very careful
you don't round this surface either then
just check that the tip sits nice and
flat on the top of your Q and if it does
and it's ready to glue it on now I'd
recommend using superglue and if
possible industrial-strength superglue
unfortunately I didn't have any
available so I'm just using regular
which isn't quite as good because it's a
lot better to get it to stick quicker
make sure you stick it on in the right
place first time
then hold it in place for a few seconds
with your fingers and then start putting
pressure on it it's at this stage I
usually push the tip into a solid
surface like this table for example to
make sure the glue fully bonds between
the cue and the tip I usually keep
pressure on it like this for 5 to 10
minutes and if possible leave it for a
few hours before moving on to the next
stage and shaping the tip now as I've
got a cue salt tip I'm gonna use one of
these handy pencil sharp and they're
looking things to help me cut it down
most of you if you're using a regular
sort of tip you'll have the right size
for the cue already but cue soul only
comes I think this is 14 mil so you've
got to really cut it down and you can't
actually do this with most types of tip
so the big pencil sharpener eventually
gets there it takes about ten minutes
but if I was to stand this all down this
would probably take me two to three
hours so when doing it like this I get
it done a lot quicker a quick tip is to
go round the top of it when you're done
at an angle so this helps to form a nice
dome that you want on top of the tip
unfortunately you can't do it all the
way but you can start to form the dome
and this will help you save a bit of
time later when you're sanding it down
like this now ideally you want to use a
file but for some reason I've lost mine
time just got a bit of sandpaper with a
blob of woods and this almost works just
as well you want to try to always sand
downwards so you're not sounding up with
some pulling the tip now I notice a lot
of players out there go for quite a
rounded tip now this does actually allow
you to grip the cue ball a little bit
better but I always go for a flatter tip
because this makes it easier to strike
the cue ball in the center more
consistently you'll notice when I finish
there's a very large amount of tip
protruding from my cue now I don't
actually mind this and with a lot of
other types of tips this wouldn't work
but the CUSO tips has got such a solid
structure that you can actually get away
with this if you're using one of these
tips and you want a more traditional
length the tip you're just going
simply have to sound it down more this
was my first go with a tip and the great
thing about CUSO tips is it they're
playable within a few shots you get that
feel automatically where with a lot of
tips they feel soft and spongy to start
off with if at this stage you get the
feeling of it just being a little bit
loose I would suggest gluing a little
tiny bit round the bottom of the tip
before taking it off again I had about
10 frames with somebody the next day
using this tip and I had a couple of 70
breaks and I already feel very happy
with it and if you want to see one of my
old videos where I review the CUSO tips
then try this video or if you want to
see five tips on snooker then try our
video snooker tips and remember don't
just watch play and make the commitment
to becoming a better player by
subscribing to the channel and visit the
website see you later
